translation: zamożny [having a lot of money or owning a lot of things]
sentence: We live in an affluent neighborhood.

translation: załagodzić, uspokoić [to prevent further disagreement in arguments or war by giving to the opposing side an advantage that they have demanded]
sentence: She claimed that the government had only changed the law in order to appease their critics.

translation: lękliwy [feeling worried about something that you are going to do or that is going to happen]
sentence: I've invited a lot of people to the party, but I'm a little apprehensive that no one will come.

translation: zgromadzenie [formal; a collection of things or a group of people or animals]
sentence: A varied assemblage of birds was probing the mud for food.

translation: banał [formal; the quality of being boring, ordinary, and not original, or something that is like this]
sentence: What's on show in this programme is the sheer banality of ordinary lives.

translation: kora [the hard outer covering of a tree]
sentence: All mature eucalypts put on an annual layer of bark, which contributes to the increasing diameter of the stems.

translation: wcześniej, z góry, uprzednio [earlier (than a particular time)]
sentence: I knew she was coming that afternoon because she had phoned beforehand to say so.

translation: spóźniony [coming later than expected]
sentence: They did make a belated attempt to reduce the noise.

translation: zadać kłam [to show something to be false, or to hide something such as an emotion]
sentence: Her calm face belied the terror she was feeling.

translation: gorący [very bright and hot; powerful and impressive]
sentence: We quickly grew tired in the blazing sunshine.

translation: kołysać się, podskakiwać [to move or make something move quickly up and down, especially in water]
sentence: Tiny boats bobbed up and down in the harbor.

translation: nora [a hole in the ground dug by an animal such as a rabbit, especially to live in]
sentence: The chipmunk retreated to its burrow to have its babies.

translation: uliczny grajek [UK; someone who sings, plays, or performs in a public place so that people will give money]
sentence: A busker was playing violin on the train platform.

translation: czystość, cnota [the state of not having sexual relationships or never having had sex]
sentence: As a monk, he took vows of chastity, poverty, and obedience.

translation: łączyć [to come together to form a single thing or group; to join two or more things or groups together to form a single one]
sentence: Hydrogen and oxygen combine to form water.

translation: zamieszanie [a sudden, short period of noise, confusion, or excited movement]
sentence: He looked up to see what all the commotion was about.

translation: przedział [one of the separate areas inside a vehicle, especially a train]
sentence: The first class compartment is at the front of the train.

translation: przyprawa [formal; a substance, such as salt, that you add to food to improve its taste]
sentence: Cinnamon is principally employed in cookery as a condiment and flavoring material, being largely used in the preparation of some kinds of chocolate and liqueurs.

translation: wierni, kongregacja [a group of people who have come together in a religious building for worship and prayer]
sentence: The priest asked the congregation to kneel.

translation: łudzić [to make someone believe something that is not true]
sentence: He's deluding himself if he thinks he's going to be promoted this year.

translation: sprzeciwiać się, wnosić obiekcję [formal; to express disagreement or refuse to do something]
sentence: The lawyer requested a break in the court case, but the judge demurred.

translation: boski [connected with a god, or like a god]
sentence: Some fans seem to regard the players as divine beings.

translation: wyjawiać [to make something secret known]
sentence: Journalists do not divulge their sources.

translation: bać się, obawiać się [to feel extremely worried or frightened about something that is going to happen or that might happen]
sentence: He's dreading the exam - he's sure he's going to fail.

translation: ponury, smętny [disapproving; boring and making you feel unhappy]
sentence: She had spent another dreary day in the office.

translation: łagodzące (okoliczności) [formal; causing a wrong act to be judged less seriously by giving reasons for it]
sentence: She was found guilty of theft, but because of extenuating circumstances was not sent to prison.

translation: kieł [a long, sharp tooth of an animal such as a dog or a snake]
sentence: The dog growled and bared its fangs.

translation: trudność [(something that causes) difficult or unpleasant conditions of life, or an example of this]
sentence: People suffered many hardships during that long winter.

translation: osobliwość, dziwactwo [a strange or unusual habit, way of behaving, or feature that someone or something has]
sentence: She often cracks her knuckles when she's speaking - it's one of her little idiosyncrasies.

translation: nieuchronny, bliski [coming or likely to happen very soon]
sentence: For a man in imminent danger of losing his job, he appeared quite unruffled.

translation: bodziec, impet [something that encourages a particular activity or makes that activity more energetic or effective]
sentence: The recent publicity surrounding homelessness has given fresh impetus to the cause.

translation: nieodpowiedni, niedogodny [formal; happening or done at a time that is not suitable or convenient]
sentence: I'm sorry, you've called at an inopportune moment.

translation: wspaniałomyślny, wielkoduszny [very kind and generous towards an enemy or someone you have defeated]
sentence: The team's manager was magnanimous in victory, and praised the losing team.

translation: prowizoryczny [temporary and of low quality, but used because of a sudden need]
sentence: Thousands of refugees are living in makeshift camps.

translation: grzywa [the long, thick hair that grows along the top of a horse's neck or around the face and neck of a lion]
sentence: The painting depicts a beautiful young man with a flowing mane of red hair.

translation: obowiązki, płaszcz [literary; the responsibilities of an important position or job, especially as given from the person who had the job to the person who replaces them]
sentence: She unsuccessfully attempted to assume the mantle of the presidency.

translation: wtrącać się, wścibiać nos [to try to change or have an influence on things that are not your responsibility, especially by criticizing in a damaging or annoying way]
sentence: My sister's always meddling in other people's affairs.

translation: nieprzewidywalny, zmienny [literary; often changing or reacting in a way that is unexpected]
sentence: Emily's mercurial temperament made her difficult to live with.

translation: drobiazgowo [very carefully, or looking at every small detail]
sentence: The metal is then minutely examined to ensure there are no cracks.

translation: podenerwowany, wyczerpany nerwowo [in a state of being upset, nervous, and worried]
sentence: She was so tired and overwrought that she burst into tears.

translation: gwałtownie spadać [to fall suddenly and quickly from a high level or position]
sentence: Her spirits plummeted at the thought of meeting him again.

translation: psisko [informal; a dog]
sentence: For one thing, there's no conflict, unless you count the tension between a guy and his untrainable pooch

translation: muskać, czyścić piórka [(usually disapproving) to spend a lot of time making yourself look attractive and then admiring your appearance]
sentence: Will you stop preening yourself in front of the mirror?

translation: cierń, kolec [one of several thin, sharp points that stick out of a plant or animal]
sentence: The fruit can be eaten once the prickles have been removed.

translation: wyrok w zawieszeniu [a period of time when a criminal must behave well and not commit any more crimes in order to avoid being sent to prison]
sentence: The judge put him on probation for two years.

translation: wątły, marny [small; weak; not effective]
sentence: My car only has a puny little engine.

translation: bezładny, nieregularny [(of a speech or piece of writing) very long and confused; (of a building) spreading in various directions with no particular pattern]
sentence: They live in a rambling old house in the country.

translation: zjełczały [(of butter, oil, etc.) tasting or smelling unpleasant because of not being fresh]
sentence: There was a rancid smell coming from the kitchen.

translation: ryza [500 sheets of paper; informal; a lot of something, especially writing]
sentence: She's written reams of poetry.

translation: uciekanie się do, rozwiązanie [formal; using something or someone as a way of getting help, especially in a difficult or dangerous situation]
sentence: It is hoped that the dispute will be settled without recourse to litigation.

translation: drzeć, rozdzierać [literary; to tear or break something violently]
sentence: They rent their clothes in grief.

translation: zbawienny [formal; having a good effect on someone or something, though often seeming unpleasant]
sentence: The accident was a salutary reminder of the dangers of climbing.

translation: zadufany w sobie [disapproving; believing that you are more important or have a higher value than other people]
sentence: He never comes across as pompous or self-important.

translation: dokładnie ten sam [exactly the same]
sentence: His father had suffered from the selfsame disease.

translation: goleń [the front part of your leg between your knee and your foot]
sentence: She has a nasty bruise on her shin.

translation: warczeć [(especially of dogs) to make a deep, rough sound while showing the teeth, usually in anger or (of people) to speak or say something angrily and forcefully]
sentence: The dogs started to snarl at each other so I had to separate them.

translation: drzazga, odłamek [a small, sharp, broken piece of wood, glass, plastic, or similar material]
sentence: The girl had a splinter of wood in her toe.

translation: mrużyć oczy [to partly close your eyes in order to see more clearly]
sentence: The sun was shining straight in her eyes and made her squint.

translation: zaskakujący, niepokojący [surprising and sometimes worrying]
sentence: He made some startling admissions about his past.

translation: rumak [literary; a horse that is ridden]
sentence: I spurred my panting steed and waved my sword.

translation: wstrząsnąć, wprawiać w osłupienie [to shock or surprise someone very much]
sentence: News of the disaster stunned people throughout the world.

translation: zlewać się potem [(of a person) to feel very hot; to be very hot in a way that makes you feel uncomfortable]
sentence: The soldiers were sweltering in their uniforms.

translation: namacalny [real and not imaginary; able to be shown, touched, or experienced]
sentence: We need tangible evidence if we're going to take legal action.

translation: lać [to rain heavily]
sentence: It's been teeming down all day.

translation: przejściowy [formal; lasting for only a short time]
sentence: A growing proportion of the population are in a transitory stage between paid employment and old age.

translation: migotać [(of light or a shiny surface) to shine repeatedly strongly then weakly, as if flashing on and off very quickly]
sentence: The lights of the town twinkled in the distance.

translation: jednoznaczny, zdecydowany [total, or expressed in a clear and certain way]
sentence: The church has been unequivocal in its condemnation of the violence.

translation: niestabilny, nieprzewidywalny [likely to change suddenly and unexpectedly, especially by getting worse]
sentence: Food and fuel prices are very volatile in a war situation.

translation: zapach, powiew [a slight smell, carried on a current of air]
sentence: He leaned towards me and I caught a whiff of garlic.

translation: kręcić się, wiercić się [to twist your body, or move part of your body, with small, quick movements]
sentence: A large worm wriggled in the freshly dug earth.
